title: 109_hr6107
content: AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR TAX LAW ENFORCEMENT RELATING TO HUMAN SEX TRAFFICKING. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2007 to establish an IRS office focusing on violations of internal revenue laws related to human sex trafficking. The text authorizes additional funding for the operations of the office established for addressing human sex trafficking violations. Any amounts appropriated will remain available for fiscal year 2008. The office will receive funding equal to the tax collected under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, plus any related penalties imposed. A report is required to be submitted within one year of the enactment date. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance within a year of the Act's enactment on the enforcement activities of the office established for human sex trafficking violations. Recommendations for statutory changes for future prosecutions must be included. Whistleblower awards under the Internal Revenue Code will apply to victims of human sex trafficking without certain restrictions. SEC. 2. WHISTLEBLOWER REFORMS. Section 7623 is amended to include new subsections regarding awards to whistleblowers. If the Secretary proceeds with an action based on information from an individual, the whistleblower may receive an award of 15-30% of the collected proceeds. The Whistleblower Office determines the award amount based on the individual's substantial contribution to the action. If the contribution is less substantial, the award is based on specific disclosures from various sources. The Whistleblower Office may award sums up to 10 percent of collected proceeds for information leading to an action, considering the significance of the information and the individual's role. This does not apply if the individual is the original source of information. The Whistleblower Office may reduce or deny an award if the individual planned and initiated actions that led to tax underpayment. If the individual is convicted of criminal conduct related to their actions, the award will be denied. Any determination regarding an award may be appealed. The Tax Court has jurisdiction over appeals regarding awards under specific paragraphs. The subsection applies to actions against taxpayers meeting income and dispute thresholds. No contract with the IRS is required for individuals to receive an award. The subsection establishes the Whistleblower Office within the IRS to analyze information and operate under the Commissioner's direction. Individuals may be represented by counsel and must submit information under penalty of perjury for award consideration. The Whistleblower Office within the IRS analyzes information received, investigates or assigns matters, monitors actions taken, informs individuals of further review, may require non-disclosure, may ask for additional assistance, and determines award amounts. The Whistleblower Office determines award amounts and may request assistance under its direction and control. Assistance funding can be reimbursed from available funds with the individual's agreement. The Secretary shall conduct a yearly study and report to Congress on the use of this section, including an analysis of the previous year's use and any recommendations for legislative or administrative changes. The Secretary shall conduct a yearly study and report to Congress on the use of this section, including an analysis of the previous year's use and any recommendations for legislative or administrative changes. Any deduction allowable under this chapter for attorney fees and court costs paid in connection with awards to whistleblowers under section 7623(b) is allowed, regardless of whether the taxpayer itemizes. The amendments made by this section apply to information provided on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Increase in criminal monetary penalty limitation for the underpayment or overpayment of tax due to fraud. Section 7201 is amended to increase the penalty to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and 10 years for attempting to evade or defeat tax. Section 7203 is amended to increase the penalty to $50,000 for willful failure to file return, supply information, or pay tax. The penalty for aggravated failure to file a tax return is increased to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and 10 years. The penalty for aggravated failure to file a tax return is increased to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and 10 years. Subsection (a) allows penalties for consecutive taxable years with aggregate tax liability over $100,000. Penalty may be applied in addition to other penalties. Section 7206 is amended regarding fraud and false statements. The penalty for aggravated failure to file a tax return is increased to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and 10 years. Section 7206 is amended to increase the monetary limitation for underpayment or overpayment of tax due to fraud. The amendments made by this section increase penalties for tax-related fraudulent actions, with a minimum dollar amount specified. The effective date for these changes applies to actions occurring after the enactment of the Act.
